tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is a prayer that Moses wrote"

tn.ref: Lord, you have been our refuge
tn.text: God protecting his people is spoken of as if God were a refuge or shelter. AT: "Lord, you have been like a shelter for us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"always" (UDB)
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Before you formed the mountains" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"created" or "shaped"
This represents everything that is in the world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This phrase represents all time past, present, and future.

This implies that just as God created the first man, Adam, from the soil, God will cause people's bodies to turn back into soil after they die. AT: "You return people to dust when they die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "man" means people in general. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
The words "to dust" or "to soil" are understood. AT: "Return to dust, you descendants" or "Return to soil, you descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This is a way of referring to humans in general. AT: "you humans" or "you people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: For a thousand years in your sight are as yesterday when it is past, and as a watch in the night
tn.text: The writer means that a long period of time seems like a short period of time to God. AT: "You consider a thousand years the same as one day in the past, or as a few short hours in the night" or "Even a thousand years is not a long time to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"1,000 years" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
Here "sight" represents thoughts or opinions. AT: "to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: You sweep them away as with a flood and they sleep
tn.text: God causing people to die suddenly is spoken of as if he swept them away with a broom. This sweeping is also spoken of as if it were a flood that carried people away. AT: "Lord, you destroy the people as with a flood and they die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This is a polite way of speaking of people dying. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: in the morning they are like the grass ... in the evening it withers and dries up
tn.text: The people are being compared to grass to emphasize that people do not live a very long time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Both of these phrases refer to how the grass grows. AT: "it begins to grow and develop" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Both of these phrases refer to how the grass dies. AT: "it fades and dries up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: we are consumed in your anger
tn.text: God destroying people in his anger is spoken of as if God's anger were a fire that completely burns up the people. This can be stated in active form. AT: "You destroy us in your anger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: and in your wrath we are terrified
tn.text: "and when you are angry we are greatly afraid"

tn.ref: You have set our iniquities before you, our hidden sins in the light of your presence
tn.text: God considering people's sins is spoken of as if sins were an objects he could place in front of himself and look at them. AT: "You see every sinful thing we do, even the sinful things we do in secret" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Our life passes away under your wrath
tn.text: The word "because" can be used to make clear that God's wrath causes human life to end. AT: "Our lives come to an end because of your wrath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])
The writer compares human life to a sigh to emphasize that life is very brief. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"70" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"80" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: even our best years are marked by trouble and sorrow
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Even in our best years we experience trouble and sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is a polite way of referring to people dying. AT: "we die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: Who knows the intensity of your anger, and your wrath that is equal to the fear of you?
tn.text: The writer uses a question to emphasize that no one has fully experienced God anger. Therefore no one truly reveres God and fears his anger when people sin. AT: "No one knows the intensity of your anger. Therefore no one fears your wrath when they sin." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Turn back, Yahweh! How long will it be?
tn.text: Asking Yahweh to no longer be angry is spoken of as if the writer wants God to turn physically away from his anger. AT: "Yahweh, please do not be angry any longer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The writer uses a question to state that he wants God to stop being angry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "your servants" refers to the people of Israel. AT: "Be merciful to us, your servants"
"Satisfy us every morning"
The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be stated as an adjective. AT: "by being faithful because of you covenant with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: in proportion to the days you afflicted us and to the years we have experienced trouble
tn.text: Both of these phrases mean the same thing. The writer is asking Yahweh to make them happy for the same amount of time he punished them. AT: "for the same amount of time that you afflicted us and caused us to suffer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "your servants" refer to the people of Israel. AT: "Let us, your servants" or "Let us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "children" means children and descendants.
The abstract noun "majesty" can be stated as "great things." AT: "see the great things you do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: May the favor of the Lord our God be ours
tn.text: The abstract noun "favor" can be stated as "be kind." AT: "May the Lord our God be kind to us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: prosper the work of our hands
tn.text: Here "hands" represents the whole person. AT: "cause us to be successful" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
